Abstract: CRISPR-based biosensing strategies have emerged as powerful tools for the detection of various biomolecules, including nucleic acids, proteins, and small molecules. This review summarizes recent advancements in the technical development of CRISPR biosensors, highlighting their unique features such as high specificity, sensitivity, and multiplexing capabilities. We discuss the integration of CRISPR systems with various signal transduction methods, such as fluorescence, electrochemistry, and colorimetry, to enhance detection performance. Additionally, the application prospects of CRISPR biosensors in clinical diagnostics, environmental monitoring, and food safety are explored. Challenges and future directions, including the need for improved stability and portability, are also addressed. This comprehensive overview provides insights into the potential of CRISPR-based biosensing technologies to revolutionize point-of-care testing and real-time monitoring.
